question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is
true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

c)
$f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{3}{x + 2} \,\,&\text{if}\,\, x < 1 \\ \sqrt{x} \,\,&\text{if}\,\, x \ge 1 \end{cases}\,\,\,$
is continuous at all real numbers.
sols:
\textbf{False:} To hunt for discontinuities, we have to check inside
each piece and also at the boundary.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  For the boundary to be continuous, we must have:

  \begin{align*}
  \lim_{x\rightarrow 1^-} f(x) &=\lim_{x\rightarrow 1^+} f(x)\\
  \lim_{x\rightarrow 1^-} \frac{3}{x+2} &=\lim_{x\rightarrow 1^+} \sqrt{x}\\
  \frac{3}{1+2} &=\sqrt{1} \\
  1&=1.\end{align*}

  So the limits exists and is equal to $1$ which happens to be
  $f(1) =1$. So the function in continuous at the boundary.
\item
  On the right of $x=1$, the function is continuous since $\sqrt{x}$ is
  only undefined for $x<0$ which is not covered by this case.
\item
  On the left of $x=1$, the function is discontinuous at $x=-2$ since
  the denominator is $0$. This fall inside the region considered. So
  $f(x)$ is discontinuous at $x=-2$.
\end{itemize}

That means $f(x)$ is NOT continuous over all real numbers.
hints:
You need to check three things:

1. That the function is continue at the break point given by $x=1$

2. That the right hand side of the function is continuous at all points
larger than 1.

3. That the left hand side of the function is continuous at all points
smaller than 1.
